## Introduction

Management Strategy Evaluation (MSE) is a simulation-based framework that tests the performance of alternative management procedures under uncertainty, providing a robust approach for evaluating fishery management strategies in complex and variable environments [@Punt2016; @Butterworth2007]. The MSE framework consists of three main components: an operating model that represents the "true" population dynamics, an observation model that simulates data collection processes, and a management procedure that encompasses stock assessment methods and harvest control rules [@Smith1999; @Rademeyer2007].

Given the computational complexity and data requirements of full MSE implementations, this chapter employs a short-cut MSE approach [@Smith2021; @Plaganyi2014]. This streamlined methodology conditions the operating model directly on the outputs from the integrated stock assessment model developed in [Chapter4](#chap4)., thereby maintaining consistency with the estimated population parameters while reducing computational burden. The operating model incorporates the estimated biomass trajectories, recruitment patterns, and associated uncertainty from the stock assessment, allowing for efficient exploration of management scenarios.

The primary objective of this MSE is to evaluate the sustainability of current krill fishery management measures, specifically the fixed Total Allowable Catch (TAC) system, under varying recruitment scenarios over the next 10-15 years. This analysis will assess the performance of existing harvest control rules in maintaining stock sustainability while accounting for recruitment variability and environmental uncertainty characteristic of the Western Antarctic Peninsula ecosystem. Through this evaluation, we aim to identify potential weaknesses in current management approaches and explore adaptive strategies that could enhance the long-term sustainability of the Antarctic krill fishery.
